qas.question: The term Carnival is very common in areas with a large presence of which religious sect?
What country no longer celebrates Carnival?
The Manila Carnival was dissolved after what year?
What is the Carnival known as in countries which are mostly Lutheran?
What is the name of the festival celebrated in Eastern Orthodox nations during the last week before Great Lent?

context: The term Carnival is traditionally used in areas with a large <a0_0>Catholic<a0_0/> presence. However, <a1_0>the Philippines<a1_0/>, a predominantly Roman Catholic country, does not celebrate Carnival anymore since the dissolution of the Manila Carnival after <a2_0>1939<a2_0/>, the last carnival in the country. In historically Lutheran countries, the celebration is known as <a3_0>Fastelavn<a3_0/>, and in areas with a high concentration of Anglicans and Methodists, pre-Lenten celebrations, along with penitential observances, occur on Shrove Tuesday. In Eastern Orthodox nations, <a4_0>Maslenitsa<a4_0/> is celebrated during the last week before Great Lent. In German-speaking Europe and the Netherlands, the Carnival season traditionally opens on 11/11 (often at 11:11 a.m.). This dates back to celebrations before the Advent season or with harvest celebrations of St. Martin's Day.
